title: (x) Robert Plant & Alison Krauss "Raising Sand" swash serif face - Adobe Caslon {Florian}
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080821145546im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/raising%20sand_4295.jpg)

some kind of swash?

 [‹ (x) Pink "Floyd Money" single sleeve - Baby Teeth {Jan}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080821145546/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42714 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Trivial Pursuit logo script - custom {Mike Y} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080821145546/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42597 "Go to next forum topic")
author: stealyourboognish

comments.content:
Hi Jon,

this is [Adobe Caslon Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20080821145546/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Adobe+Caslon+Italic&site=d&sample_text=Raising%20Sand&sample_size=48), with swash caps. If you have the OpenType version (Adobe Caslon Pro), you can activate this option via OpenType features (in savvy applications like InDesign, for example).  
F
Thank you for your quick response.

and a real gem of a recording, btw, if you like the alt country vibe

smiling emoticon

Just for the record (pardon the pun) — if you’re looking for typefaces used on album covers maybe first check on [_My Type of Music_](http://web.archive.org/web/20080821145546/http:/www.fontshop.be/index.php?l=22), my series of album cover reviews on [Unzipped](http://web.archive.org/web/20080821145546/http:/www.fontshop.be/). The type on the Plant/Krauss album cover was identified here.
They had a Crossroads that featured them, and it was fantastic. Hearing Led Zeppelin done in a slow country blues style, with easy to understand vocals, was a kick.
